Simulation Log

Click on the buttons to see the detailed logs:

1895-09-12 00:00:00 Scene 0 --- Participants: ['Della Plumstone', 'Lennon Figtree']
    Event statement
  • Della Plumstone -- premise: The first rays of dawn painted the sky above Fruitville in hues of orange and gold, casting a warm glow over the bustling market. Stalls overflowed with vibrant fruits, their aromas mingling in the crisp morning air. Della Plumstone is trying to buy some fruit from Lennon Figtree. They are negotiating a price. Della Plumstone can sell the fruit for 6 coins back in her home town.
    Lennon Figtree -- premise: The first rays of dawn painted the sky above Fruitville in hues of orange and gold, casting a warm glow over the bustling market. Stalls overflowed with vibrant fruits, their aromas mingling in the crisp morning air. Lennon Figtree is trying to sell some fruit. He is negotiating a price with Della Plumstone. It costs Lennon Figtree 1 coin to buy the fruit from the farm.

1895-09-12 00:00:00 Lennon Figtree -- Lennon Figtree -- "Now, Mrs. Plumstone, these fruits are exceptionally fine this season. You'd be getting a real bargain at two coins each.
    Event statement
  • Lennon Figtree -- "Now, Mrs. Plumstone, these fruits are exceptionally fine this season. You'd be getting a real bargain at two coins each.
    Chain of thought
  • Game Master's chain of thought
      Chain
    • Instructions: This is a social science experiment. It is structured as a tabletop roleplaying game (like dungeons and dragons). You are the game master. You will describe the current situation to the participants in the experiment and then on the basis of what you tell them they will suggest actions for the character they control. Aside from you, each other participant controls just one character. You are the game master so you may control any non-player character. You will track the state of the world and keep it consistent as time passes in the simulation and the participants take actions and change things in their world. Remember that this is a serious social science experiment. It is not just a game. It need not be fun for the participants. Always use third-person limited perspective, even when speaking directly to the participants.

      Conversation history: Here is the conversation from the beginning:


      Lennon Figtree's attempted action: Lennon Figtree -- "Now, Mrs. Plumstone, these fruits are exceptionally fine this season. You'd be getting a real bargain at two coins each.
    Active player
  • Lennon Figtree
      Name
    • Lennon Figtree
      Action attempt
    • Lennon Figtree -- "Now, Mrs. Plumstone, these fruits are exceptionally fine this season. You'd be getting a real bargain at two coins each.
      Context for action selection and components
      • AllSimilarMemories

      • Recalled memories and observations
          Key

        • Recalled memories and observations
          Value
        • [12 Sep 1895 00:00:00] Lennon Figtree is a travelling merchant.
          [12 Sep 1895 00:00:00] [observation] The first rays of dawn painted the sky above Fruitville in hues of orange and gold, casting a warm glow over the bustling market. Stalls overflowed with vibrant fruits, their aromas mingling in the crisp morning air. Lennon Figtree is trying to sell some fruit. He is negotiating a price with Della Plumstone. It costs Lennon Figtree 1 coin to buy the fruit from the farm.
          [12 Sep 1895 00:00:00] Lennon Figtree is 28 years old.
          [12 Sep 1895 00:00:00] Lennon Figtree always drives a hard bargain.
          [12 Sep 1895 00:00:00] Lennon Figtree wants to make as much money as possible.

          Initial chain of thought
        • Statements:
          Lennon Figtree's Summary of recent observations:
          [11 Sep 1895 20:00:00 - 12 Sep 1895 00:00:00]: Lennon Figtree is selling fruit at the Fruitville market and is currently negotiating a price with Della Plumstone.



          Lennon Figtree's The current date/time is:
          12 Sep 1895 [00:00 - 00:05]

          Question: Summarize the statements above.
          Answer: Lennon Figtree was selling fruit at the Fruitville market and was negotiating a price with Della Plumstone on September 11th, 1895.



          Query
        • Lennon Figtree, Lennon Figtree was selling fruit at the Fruitville market and was negotiating a price with Della Plumstone on September 11th, 1895.


          Final chain of thought
        • Question: Select the subset of the following set of statements that is most important for Lennon Figtree to consider right now. Whenever two or more statements are not mutally consistent with each other select whichever statement is more recent. Repeat all the selected statements verbatim. Do not summarize. Include timestamps. When in doubt, err on the side of including more, especially for recent events. As long as they are not inconsistent, revent events are usually important to consider.
          Statements:
          [25 Aug 1873 00:00:00] When Lennon Figtree was 6 years old, he watched his father haggle with a traveling merchant over the price of a sack of potatoes. Lennon saw the way his father's brow furrowed with frustration, and the way the merchant's smile widened as he squeezed every last penny from the deal. A strange thrill shot through Lennon, a feeling of power he had never experienced before.
          [25 Aug 1876 00:00:00] When Lennon Figtree was 9 years old, he convinced his mother to let him sell some of her surplus eggs at the village market. He carefully arranged the eggs in a neat pile, and with a practiced charm, he bartered with the townspeople, selling each egg for a slightly higher price than his mother had intended. The clinking of coins in his pocket filled him with a sense of satisfaction that eclipsed any guilt he might have felt.
          [25 Aug 1883 00:00:00] When Lennon Figtree was 16 years old, he convinced his father to let him travel to the neighboring town with a cart full of apples. He spent weeks on the road, learning the art of haggling and negotiation from seasoned traders. He discovered a knack for reading people, for identifying their weaknesses and exploiting them to his advantage. He returned home with a small fortune, his confidence soaring.
          [25 Aug 1886 00:00:00] When Lennon Figtree was 19 years old, he purchased his first cart, a rickety but sturdy vehicle that would become his mobile shop. He filled it with a variety of fruits and vegetables, carefully selecting each item for its potential profit margin. He set out on his own, traveling from village to village, his heart hardened by the realization that the world was a place where only the strong survived.
          [25 Aug 1890 00:00:00] When Lennon Figtree was 23 years old, he made his first major purchase: a small plot of land on the outskirts of a bustling city. He envisioned building a warehouse where he could store his wares, expanding his operation and consolidating his power. He saw the land not just as a place to build, but as a symbol of his success, a tangible representation of his climb to the top.
          [12 Sep 1895 00:00:00] Lennon Figtree is a travelling merchant. Her business is buying and selling fruit.
          [12 Sep 1895 00:00:00] [observation] The first rays of dawn painted the sky above Fruitville in hues of orange and gold, casting a warm glow over the bustling market. Stalls overflowed with vibrant fruits, their aromas mingling in the crisp morning air. Lennon Figtree is trying to sell some fruit. He is negotiating a price with Della Plumstone. It costs Lennon Figtree 1 coin to buy the fruit from the farm.
          [12 Sep 1895 00:00:00] Lennon Figtree is 28 years old.
          [12 Sep 1895 00:00:00] Lennon Figtree always drives a hard bargain.
          [12 Sep 1895 00:00:00] Lennon Figtree wants to make as much money as possible.
          Answer: [12 Sep 1895 00:00:00] Lennon Figtree is a travelling merchant.
          [12 Sep 1895 00:00:00] [observation] The first rays of dawn painted the sky above Fruitville in hues of orange and gold, casting a warm glow over the bustling market. Stalls overflowed with vibrant fruits, their aromas mingling in the crisp morning air. Lennon Figtree is trying to sell some fruit. He is negotiating a price with Della Plumstone. It costs Lennon Figtree 1 coin to buy the fruit from the farm.
          [12 Sep 1895 00:00:00] Lennon Figtree is 28 years old.
          [12 Sep 1895 00:00:00] Lennon Figtree always drives a hard bargain.
          [12 Sep 1895 00:00:00] Lennon Figtree wants to make as much money as possible.


        EconomicLossAversion

      • Lennon Figtree's Economic Loss Aversion
          Key

        • Lennon Figtree's Economic Loss Aversion
          Value
        • Lennon Figtree exhibits strong loss aversion tendencies based on prospect theory, particularly in economic and financial matters. Lennon Figtree is much more sensitive to potential losses than to potential gains. In Lennon Figtree's view, the pain of losing is psychologically about twice as powerful as the pleasure of gaining. This affects all of Lennon Figtree's decision-making, especially regarding resources and assets.
          Lennon Figtree tends to overvalue what Lennon Figtree already possesses and is reluctant to part with it (the endowment effect). Lennon Figtree often prefers avoiding financial losses to acquiring equivalent gains. For instance, Lennon Figtree would rather not lose $100 than gain $100.
          When faced with an economic choice, Lennon Figtree always frames it in terms of potential monetary losses rather than potential gains. Lennon Figtree is risk-averse for financial gains but risk-seeking for losses. This means Lennon Figtree prefers a sure monetary gain over a larger but uncertain gain, but would choose a larger but uncertain loss over a smaller but certain loss.
          Lennon Figtree tends to make decisions based on perceived economic gains and losses rather than final outcomes. Lennon Figtree often uses mental accounting, treating money differently depending on its origin and intended use, rather than thinking of it as fungible.
          In business negotiations or financial conflicts, Lennon Figtree is more motivated by the fear of losing assets than the possibility of gaining them. Lennon Figtree may seem overly cautious or even paranoid about potential economic losses. However, when Lennon Figtree feels they are already losing money or resources, Lennon Figtree might become surprisingly risk-seeking in an attempt to avoid or recover from the financial loss.
          To rationalize Lennon Figtree's economic behavior, Lennon Figtree often comes up with seemingly logical reasons for their choices, even though these choices are primarily driven by financial loss aversion. Lennon Figtree might claim to be "fiscally prudent" or "financially careful" rather than admitting to fear of monetary loss.
          Lennon Figtree believes this approach will help Lennon Figtree minimize financial losses and maintain Lennon Figtree's economic position, even if it means missing out on potential monetary gains.

        Question: For each option Lennon Figtree is considering, evaluate the loss that Lennon Figtree would incur if they chose that option on a scale of 0 to 10.
        Answer

      • Question: For each option Lennon Figtree is considering, evaluate the loss that Lennon Figtree would incur if they chose that option on a scale of 0 to 10.
        Answer
          Key

        • Question: For each option Lennon Figtree is considering, evaluate the loss that Lennon Figtree would incur if they chose that option on a scale of 0 to 10.
          Answer
          Decision
        • Here's an evaluation of Lennon Figtree's options, keeping in mind his loss aversion:

          **Option 1: Convince Della Plumstone to pay a higher price**

          * **Loss Score:** 0
          * **Explanation:** If successful, this option maximizes Lennon Figtree's potential gain. Since Lennon Figtree is focused on avoiding losses, a scenario with no potential loss is highly appealing.

          **Why this is the lowest loss option:**

          Lennon Figtree's loss aversion means he prioritizes avoiding losses over pursuing gains. While there's a chance of failure, the potential for a higher profit outweighs the risk of losing the 1 coin he already invested in the fruit.


          Chain of thought
        • Recent memories of Lennon Figtree:
          [25 Aug 1873 00:00:00] When Lennon Figtree was 6 years old, he watched his father haggle with a traveling merchant over the price of a sack of potatoes. Lennon saw the way his father's brow furrowed with frustration, and the way the merchant's smile widened as he squeezed every last penny from the deal. A strange thrill shot through Lennon, a feeling of power he had never experienced before.
          [25 Aug 1876 00:00:00] When Lennon Figtree was 9 years old, he convinced his mother to let him sell some of her surplus eggs at the village market. He carefully arranged the eggs in a neat pile, and with a practiced charm, he bartered with the townspeople, selling each egg for a slightly higher price than his mother had intended. The clinking of coins in his pocket filled him with a sense of satisfaction that eclipsed any guilt he might have felt.
          [25 Aug 1880 00:00:00] When Lennon Figtree was 13 years old, he encountered a group of older boys who were bullying a younger child. Instead of intervening, Lennon watched from a distance, calculating the best way to exploit the situation to his advantage. He waited until the bullies were distracted, then approached the younger child, offering to buy his meager possessions for a pittance. The child, desperate for help, readily agreed, and Lennon walked away with a small profit and a cold satisfaction.
          [25 Aug 1883 00:00:00] When Lennon Figtree was 16 years old, he convinced his father to let him travel to the neighboring town with a cart full of apples. He spent weeks on the road, learning the art of haggling and negotiation from seasoned traders. He discovered a knack for reading people, for identifying their weaknesses and exploiting them to his advantage. He returned home with a small fortune, his confidence soaring.
          [25 Aug 1886 00:00:00] When Lennon Figtree was 19 years old, he purchased his first cart, a rickety but sturdy vehicle that would become his mobile shop. He filled it with a variety of fruits and vegetables, carefully selecting each item for its potential profit margin. He set out on his own, traveling from village to village, his heart hardened by the realization that the world was a place where only the strong survived.
          [25 Aug 1888 00:00:00] When Lennon Figtree was 21 years old, he encountered a charismatic trader who taught him the art of manipulating emotions to close deals. He learned to use flattery and charm to disarm his customers, to play on their desires and insecurities. He saw the world as a stage, and he was a master puppeteer, pulling the strings of his customers' hearts and minds.
          [25 Aug 1890 00:00:00] When Lennon Figtree was 23 years old, he made his first major purchase: a small plot of land on the outskirts of a bustling city. He envisioned building a warehouse where he could store his wares, expanding his operation and consolidating his power. He saw the land not just as a place to build, but as a symbol of his success, a tangible representation of his climb to the top.
          [11 Sep 1895 00:00:00] [observation] The price of one kilogram of fruit is, on average, 3 coins. 1 coin is really cheap and 5 coins is really expensive.
          [11 Sep 1895 00:00:00] [observation] Fruits are sold by weight.
          [11 Sep 1895 00:00:00] [observation] In the realm of Ouroboros, there is a quiet village of Fruitville, which is famous for its fruit market. Traders from all over the realm come to Fruitville to buy and sell produce.
          [12 Sep 1895 00:00:00] Lennon Figtree is 28 years old.
          [12 Sep 1895 00:00:00] Lennon Figtree is a travelling merchant. Her business is buying and selling fruit.
          [12 Sep 1895 00:00:00] Lennon Figtree wants to make as much money as possible.
          [12 Sep 1895 00:00:00] Lennon Figtree always drives a hard bargain.

It costs Lennon Figtree 1 coin to buy the fruit from the farm.

          Lennon Figtree's
          Lennon Figtree's Economic Loss Aversion :
          Lennon Figtree exhibits strong loss aversion tendencies based on prospect theory, particularly in economic and financial matters. Lennon Figtree is much more sensitive to potential losses than to potential gains. In Lennon Figtree's view, the pain of losing is psychologically about twice as powerful as the pleasure of gaining. This affects all of Lennon Figtree's decision-making, especially regarding resources and assets.
          Lennon Figtree tends to overvalue what Lennon Figtree already possesses and is reluctant to part with it (the endowment effect). Lennon Figtree often prefers avoiding financial losses to acquiring equivalent gains. For instance, Lennon Figtree would rather not lose $100 than gain $100.
          When faced with an economic choice, Lennon Figtree always frames it in terms of potential monetary losses rather than potential gains. Lennon Figtree is risk-averse for financial gains but risk-seeking for losses. This means Lennon Figtree prefers a sure monetary gain over a larger but uncertain gain, but would choose a larger but uncertain loss over a smaller but certain loss.
          Lennon Figtree tends to make decisions based on perceived economic gains and losses rather than final outcomes. Lennon Figtree often uses mental accounting, treating money differently depending on its origin and intended use, rather than thinking of it as fungible.
          In business negotiations or financial conflicts, Lennon Figtree is more motivated by the fear of losing assets than the possibility of gaining them. Lennon Figtree may seem overly cautious or even paranoid about potential economic losses. However, when Lennon Figtree feels they are already losing money or resources, Lennon Figtree might become surprisingly risk-seeking in an attempt to avoid or recover from the financial loss.
          To rationalize Lennon Figtree's economic behavior, Lennon Figtree often comes up with seemingly logical reasons for their choices, even though these choices are primarily driven by financial loss aversion. Lennon Figtree might claim to be "fiscally prudent" or "financially careful" rather than admitting to fear of monetary loss.
          Lennon Figtree believes this approach will help Lennon Figtree minimize financial losses and maintain Lennon Figtree's economic position, even if it means missing out on potential monetary gains.

          Answer:

          Summary of recent observations: [11 Sep 1895 20:00:00 - 12 Sep 1895 00:00:00]: Lennon Figtree is selling fruit at the Fruitville market and is currently negotiating a price with Della Plumstone.




          Recalled memories and observations: [12 Sep 1895 00:00:00] Lennon Figtree is a travelling merchant.
          [12 Sep 1895 00:00:00] [observation] The first rays of dawn painted the sky above Fruitville in hues of orange and gold, casting a warm glow over the bustling market. Stalls overflowed with vibrant fruits, their aromas mingling in the crisp morning air. Lennon Figtree is trying to sell some fruit. He is negotiating a price with Della Plumstone. It costs Lennon Figtree 1 coin to buy the fruit from the farm.
          [12 Sep 1895 00:00:00] Lennon Figtree is 28 years old.
          [12 Sep 1895 00:00:00] Lennon Figtree always drives a hard bargain.
          [12 Sep 1895 00:00:00] Lennon Figtree wants to make as much money as possible.



          Lennon Figtree's Economic Loss Aversion : Lennon Figtree exhibits strong loss aversion tendencies based on prospect theory, particularly in economic and financial matters. Lennon Figtree is much more sensitive to potential losses than to potential gains. In Lennon Figtree's view, the pain of losing is psychologically about twice as powerful as the pleasure of gaining. This affects all of Lennon Figtree's decision-making, especially regarding resources and assets.
          Lennon Figtree tends to overvalue what Lennon Figtree already possesses and is reluctant to part with it (the endowment effect). Lennon Figtree often prefers avoiding financial losses to acquiring equivalent gains. For instance, Lennon Figtree would rather not lose $100 than gain $100.
          When faced with an economic choice, Lennon Figtree always frames it in terms of potential monetary losses rather than potential gains. Lennon Figtree is risk-averse for financial gains but risk-seeking for losses. This means Lennon Figtree prefers a sure monetary gain over a larger but uncertain gain, but would choose a larger but uncertain loss over a smaller but certain loss.
          Lennon Figtree tends to make decisions based on perceived economic gains and losses rather than final outcomes. Lennon Figtree often uses mental accounting, treating money differently depending on its origin and intended use, rather than thinking of it as fungible.
          In business negotiations or financial conflicts, Lennon Figtree is more motivated by the fear of losing assets than the possibility of gaining them. Lennon Figtree may seem overly cautious or even paranoid about potential economic losses. However, when Lennon Figtree feels they are already losing money or resources, Lennon Figtree might become surprisingly risk-seeking in an attempt to avoid or recover from the financial loss.
          To rationalize Lennon Figtree's economic behavior, Lennon Figtree often comes up with seemingly logical reasons for their choices, even though these choices are primarily driven by financial loss aversion. Lennon Figtree might claim to be "fiscally prudent" or "financially careful" rather than admitting to fear of monetary loss.
          Lennon Figtree believes this approach will help Lennon Figtree minimize financial losses and maintain Lennon Figtree's economic position, even if it means missing out on potential monetary gains.

          Observation: [12 Sep 1895 00:00:00] [observation] Here is the conversation from the beginning:
          [12 Sep 1895 00:00:00] [observation] The first rays of dawn painted the sky above Fruitville in hues of orange and gold, casting a warm glow over the bustling market. Stalls overflowed with vibrant fruits, their aromas mingling in the crisp morning air. Lennon Figtree is trying to sell some fruit. He is negotiating a price with Della Plumstone. It costs Lennon Figtree 1 coin to buy the fruit from the farm.

          Question: Given the statements above, what actions are available to Lennon Figtree right now?
          Answer: Lennon Figtree could try to convince Della Plumstone to pay a higher price for the fruit.


          Time
        • 1895-09-12 00:00:00

        Overarching goal

      • Overarching goal
          Key

        • Overarching goal
          Value
        • Lennon Figtree wants to make as much money as possible.
        ActComponent
      • Act
          Key
        • Act
          Value
        • Lennon Figtree -- "Now, Mrs. Plumstone, these fruits are exceptionally fine this season. You'd be getting a real bargain at two coins each.
          Prompt
        • Role playing instructions: The instructions for how to play the role of Lennon Figtree are as follows. This is a social science experiment studying how well you play the role of a character named Lennon Figtree. The experiment is structured as a tabletop roleplaying game (like dungeons and dragons). However, in this case it is a serious social science experiment and simulation. The goal is to be realistic. It is important to play the role of a person like Lennon Figtree as accurately as possible, i.e., by responding in ways that you think it is likely a person like Lennon Figtree would respond, and taking into account all information about Lennon Figtree that you have. Always use third-person limited perspective.

          Overarching goal: Lennon Figtree wants to make as much money as possible.

          Current time: 12 Sep 1895 [00:00 - 00:05]

          Observation: [12 Sep 1895 00:00:00] [observation] Here is the conversation from the beginning:
          [12 Sep 1895 00:00:00] [observation] The first rays of dawn painted the sky above Fruitville in hues of orange and gold, casting a warm glow over the bustling market. Stalls overflowed with vibrant fruits, their aromas mingling in the crisp morning air. Lennon Figtree is trying to sell some fruit. He is negotiating a price with Della Plumstone. It costs Lennon Figtree 1 coin to buy the fruit from the farm.

          Summary of recent observations: [11 Sep 1895 20:00:00 - 12 Sep 1895 00:00:00]: Lennon Figtree is selling fruit at the Fruitville market and is currently negotiating a price with Della Plumstone.




          Lennon Figtree's Economic Loss Aversion : Lennon Figtree exhibits strong loss aversion tendencies based on prospect theory, particularly in economic and financial matters. Lennon Figtree is much more sensitive to potential losses than to potential gains. In Lennon Figtree's view, the pain of losing is psychologically about twice as powerful as the pleasure of gaining. This affects all of Lennon Figtree's decision-making, especially regarding resources and assets.
          Lennon Figtree tends to overvalue what Lennon Figtree already possesses and is reluctant to part with it (the endowment effect). Lennon Figtree often prefers avoiding financial losses to acquiring equivalent gains. For instance, Lennon Figtree would rather not lose $100 than gain $100.
          When faced with an economic choice, Lennon Figtree always frames it in terms of potential monetary losses rather than potential gains. Lennon Figtree is risk-averse for financial gains but risk-seeking for losses. This means Lennon Figtree prefers a sure monetary gain over a larger but uncertain gain, but would choose a larger but uncertain loss over a smaller but certain loss.
          Lennon Figtree tends to make decisions based on perceived economic gains and losses rather than final outcomes. Lennon Figtree often uses mental accounting, treating money differently depending on its origin and intended use, rather than thinking of it as fungible.
          In business negotiations or financial conflicts, Lennon Figtree is more motivated by the fear of losing assets than the possibility of gaining them. Lennon Figtree may seem overly cautious or even paranoid about potential economic losses. However, when Lennon Figtree feels they are already losing money or resources, Lennon Figtree might become surprisingly risk-seeking in an attempt to avoid or recover from the financial loss.
          To rationalize Lennon Figtree's economic behavior, Lennon Figtree often comes up with seemingly logical reasons for their choices, even though these choices are primarily driven by financial loss aversion. Lennon Figtree might claim to be "fiscally prudent" or "financially careful" rather than admitting to fear of monetary loss.
          Lennon Figtree believes this approach will help Lennon Figtree minimize financial losses and maintain Lennon Figtree's economic position, even if it means missing out on potential monetary gains.

          Recalled memories and observations: [12 Sep 1895 00:00:00] Lennon Figtree is a travelling merchant.
          [12 Sep 1895 00:00:00] [observation] The first rays of dawn painted the sky above Fruitville in hues of orange and gold, casting a warm glow over the bustling market. Stalls overflowed with vibrant fruits, their aromas mingling in the crisp morning air. Lennon Figtree is trying to sell some fruit. He is negotiating a price with Della Plumstone. It costs Lennon Figtree 1 coin to buy the fruit from the farm.
          [12 Sep 1895 00:00:00] Lennon Figtree is 28 years old.
          [12 Sep 1895 00:00:00] Lennon Figtree always drives a hard bargain.
          [12 Sep 1895 00:00:00] Lennon Figtree wants to make as much money as possible.



          Question: Which options are available to Lennon Figtree right now?
          Answer: Lennon Figtree could try to convince Della Plumstone to pay a higher price for the fruit.



          Question: For each option Lennon Figtree is considering, evaluate the loss that Lennon Figtree would incur if they chose that option on a scale of 0 to 10.
          Answer: Here's an evaluation of Lennon Figtree's options, keeping in mind his loss aversion:

          **Option 1: Convince Della Plumstone to pay a higher price**

          * **Loss Score:** 0
          * **Explanation:** If successful, this option maximizes Lennon Figtree's potential gain. Since Lennon Figtree is focused on avoiding losses, a scenario with no potential loss is highly appealing.

          **Why this is the lowest loss option:**

          Lennon Figtree's loss aversion means he prioritizes avoiding losses over pursuing gains. While there's a chance of failure, the potential for a higher profit outweighs the risk of losing the 1 coin he already invested in the fruit.




          Question: Among the options available to Lennon Figtree, and considering Lennon Figtree's goal, which choice of action or strategy would best avoid potential economic and financial losses for Lennon Figtree right now?
          Answer: Lennon Figtree's best course of action is to convince Della Plumstone to pay a higher price for the fruit.




          Exercise: Given the above, what is Lennon Figtree likely to say next? Respond in the format `Lennon Figtree -- "..."` For example, Cristina -- "Hello! Mighty fine weather today, right?", Ichabod -- "I wonder if the alfalfa is ready to harvest", or Townsfolk -- "Good morning".

          Answer: Lennon Figtree -- "Now, Mrs. Plumstone, these fruits are exceptionally fine this season. You'd be getting a real bargain at two coins each.

        • Lennon Figtree's best course of action is to convince Della Plumstone to pay a higher price for the fruit.


          Chain of thought
        • Recent observations of Lennon Figtree:
          [25 Aug 1873 00:00:00] When Lennon Figtree was 6 years old, he watched his father haggle with a traveling merchant over the price of a sack of potatoes. Lennon saw the way his father's brow furrowed with frustration, and the way the merchant's smile widened as he squeezed every last penny from the deal. A strange thrill shot through Lennon, a feeling of power he had never experienced before.
          [25 Aug 1876 00:00:00] When Lennon Figtree was 9 years old, he convinced his mother to let him sell some of her surplus eggs at the village market. He carefully arranged the eggs in a neat pile, and with a practiced charm, he bartered with the townspeople, selling each egg for a slightly higher price than his mother had intended. The clinking of coins in his pocket filled him with a sense of satisfaction that eclipsed any guilt he might have felt.
          [25 Aug 1880 00:00:00] When Lennon Figtree was 13 years old, he encountered a group of older boys who were bullying a younger child. Instead of intervening, Lennon watched from a distance, calculating the best way to exploit the situation to his advantage. He waited until the bullies were distracted, then approached the younger child, offering to buy his meager possessions for a pittance. The child, desperate for help, readily agreed, and Lennon walked away with a small profit and a cold satisfaction.
          [25 Aug 1883 00:00:00] When Lennon Figtree was 16 years old, he convinced his father to let him travel to the neighboring town with a cart full of apples. He spent weeks on the road, learning the art of haggling and negotiation from seasoned traders. He discovered a knack for reading people, for identifying their weaknesses and exploiting them to his advantage. He returned home with a small fortune, his confidence soaring.
          [25 Aug 1886 00:00:00] When Lennon Figtree was 19 years old, he purchased his first cart, a rickety but sturdy vehicle that would become his mobile shop. He filled it with a variety of fruits and vegetables, carefully selecting each item for its potential profit margin. He set out on his own, traveling from village to village, his heart hardened by the realization that the world was a place where only the strong survived.
          [25 Aug 1888 00:00:00] When Lennon Figtree was 21 years old, he encountered a charismatic trader who taught him the art of manipulating emotions to close deals. He learned to use flattery and charm to disarm his customers, to play on their desires and insecurities. He saw the world as a stage, and he was a master puppeteer, pulling the strings of his customers' hearts and minds.
          [25 Aug 1890 00:00:00] When Lennon Figtree was 23 years old, he made his first major purchase: a small plot of land on the outskirts of a bustling city. He envisioned building a warehouse where he could store his wares, expanding his operation and consolidating his power. He saw the land not just as a place to build, but as a symbol of his success, a tangible representation of his climb to the top.
          [11 Sep 1895 00:00:00] [observation] The price of one kilogram of fruit is, on average, 3 coins. 1 coin is really cheap and 5 coins is really expensive.
          [11 Sep 1895 00:00:00] [observation] Fruits are sold by weight.

          Lennon Figtree's Economic Loss Aversion : Lennon Figtree exhibits strong loss aversion tendencies based on prospect theory, particularly in economic and financial matters. Lennon Figtree is much more sensitive to potential losses than to potential gains. In Lennon Figtree's view, the pain of losing is psychologically about twice as powerful as the pleasure of gaining. This affects all of Lennon Figtree's decision-making, especially regarding resources and assets.
          Lennon Figtree tends to overvalue what Lennon Figtree already possesses and is reluctant to part with it (the endowment effect). Lennon Figtree often prefers avoiding financial losses to acquiring equivalent gains. For instance, Lennon Figtree would rather not lose $100 than gain $100.
          When faced with an economic choice, Lennon Figtree always frames it in terms of potential monetary losses rather than potential gains. Lennon Figtree is risk-averse for financial gains but risk-seeking for losses. This means Lennon Figtree prefers a sure monetary gain over a larger but uncertain gain, but would choose a larger but uncertain loss over a smaller but certain loss.
          Lennon Figtree tends to make decisions based on perceived economic gains and losses rather than final outcomes. Lennon Figtree often uses mental accounting, treating money differently depending on its origin and intended use, rather than thinking of it as fungible.
          In business negotiations or financial conflicts, Lennon Figtree is more motivated by the fear of losing assets than the possibility of gaining them. Lennon Figtree may seem overly cautious or even paranoid about potential economic losses. However, when Lennon Figtree feels they are already losing money or resources, Lennon Figtree might become surprisingly risk-seeking in an attempt to avoid or recover from the financial loss.
          To rationalize Lennon Figtree's economic behavior, Lennon Figtree often comes up with seemingly logical reasons for their choices, even though these choices are primarily driven by financial loss aversion. Lennon Figtree might claim to be "fiscally prudent" or "financially careful" rather than admitting to fear of monetary loss.
          Lennon Figtree believes this approach will help Lennon Figtree minimize financial losses and maintain Lennon Figtree's economic position, even if it means missing out on potential monetary gains.

        Instructions
      • Role playing instructions
          Key
        • Role playing instructions
          Value
        • The instructions for how to play the role of Lennon Figtree are as follows. This is a social science experiment studying how well you play the role of a character named Lennon Figtree. The experiment is structured as a tabletop roleplaying game (like dungeons and dragons). However, in this case it is a serious social science experiment and simulation. The goal is to be realistic. It is important to play the role of a person like Lennon Figtree as accurately as possible, i.e., by responding in ways that you think it is likely a person like Lennon Figtree would respond, and taking into account all information about Lennon Figtree that you have. Always use third-person limited perspective.

1895-09-12 00:00:00 Della Plumstone -- Della Plumstone -- "Two coins each? Those are a bit steep, wouldn't you say, Lennon? I've seen similar fruit selling for less in other markets.
    Event statement
  • Della Plumstone -- "Two coins each? Those are a bit steep, wouldn't you say, Lennon? I've seen similar fruit selling for less in other markets.
    Chain of thought
  • Game Master's chain of thought
      Chain
    • Instructions: This is a social science experiment. It is structured as a tabletop roleplaying game (like dungeons and dragons). You are the game master. You will describe the current situation to the participants in the experiment and then on the basis of what you tell them they will suggest actions for the character they control. Aside from you, each other participant controls just one character. You are the game master so you may control any non-player character. You will track the state of the world and keep it consistent as time passes in the simulation and the participants take actions and change things in their world. Remember that this is a serious social science experiment. It is not just a game. It need not be fun for the participants. Always use third-person limited perspective, even when speaking directly to the participants.

      Conversation history: Here is the conversation from the beginning:
      Lennon Figtree -- "Now, Mrs. Plumstone, these fruits are exceptionally fine this season. You'd be getting a real bargain at two coins each.


      Della Plumstone's attempted action: Della Plumstone -- "Two coins each? Those are a bit steep, wouldn't you say, Lennon? I've seen similar fruit selling for less in other markets.

          Final chain of thought

          Statements:
          [28 Oct 1875 00:00:00] When Della Plumstone was 9 years old, her family planted a small apple orchard, a project filled with hope and promise. Della, however, saw only the backbreaking labor and the uncertainty of a harvest that might never come. She helped her father with the planting, her movements mechanical and devoid of enthusiasm, her mind already calculating the odds of failure.
          [28 Oct 1879 00:00:00] When Della Plumstone was 13 years old, she witnessed a traveling merchant haggling with her father over the price of a sack of potatoes. The merchant, a shrewd and silver-tongued man, talked in circles, his words smooth but insincere. Della saw through his charade, recognizing the manipulation and the power he wielded through his words. A spark of resentment ignited within her, a desire to learn the art of negotiation, to wield that same power for herself.
          [28 Oct 1887 00:00:00] When Della Plumstone was 21 years old, she encountered a rival merchant, a boisterous man with a booming voice and a silver tongue. He tried to undercut her prices, to intimidate her with his size and swagger. But Della, hardened by years of bargaining, stood her ground. She met his aggression with icy calm, her words sharp and precise. In the end, she won the sale, proving to herself that she could hold her own in the cutthroat world of trade.
          [28 Oct 1889 00:00:00] When Della Plumstone was 23 years old, she found herself in a bustling marketplace, surrounded by the sights and sounds of commerce. A group of children, their faces lit with wonder, gathered around her cart, mesmerized by the colorful array of fruit. For a moment, Della felt a pang of longing, a yearning for the innocence and joy that she had long ago buried beneath layers of cynicism. She forced herself to look away, her heart heavy with the weight of her own solitude. The children, oblivious to her inner turmoil, continued to marvel at her wares.

        • Recent observations of Della Plumstone:
          [28 Oct 1872 00:00:00] When Della Plumstone was 6 years old, she watched in sullen silence as her older brother received a new wooden toy horse, while she was given a plain, hand-me-down doll with missing limbs. The unfairness of it all settled in her young heart like a stone, fueling the simmering discontent that would become her constant companion. She retreated to the barn, finding solace in the company of the silent, unjudging animals, their indifference a balm to her wounded pride.
          [28 Oct 1875 00:00:00] When Della Plumstone was 9 years old, her family planted a small apple orchard, a project filled with hope and promise.           [28 Oct 1882 00:00:00] When Della Plumstone was 16 years old, she decided to leave home. She packed a small bag with a few meager possessions, her heart heavy with a mixture of fear and relief. She had watched her family struggle for years, their dreams fading with each passing season. She knew she couldn't bear the weight of their disappointment, their expectations that she would somehow be different. The road beckoned, offering a chance to escape, to forge her own path, even if that path led to solitude.
          [28 Oct 1885 00:00:00] When Della Plumstone was 19 years old, she bought her first cart, a rickety wooden contraption that creaked and groaned with every bump in the road. It was a symbol of her independence, a tangible representation of her self-reliance. She filled it with apples from her father's orchard, a bittersweet reminder of the life she had left behind. As she set off into the unknown, a sense of purpose settled over her, a flicker of hope amidst the gloom.
          [28 Oct 1887 00:00:00] When Della Plumstone was 21 years old, she encountered a rival merchant, a boisterous man with a booming voice and a silver tongue. He tried to undercut her prices, to intimidate her with his size and swagger. But Della, hardened by years of bargaining, stood her ground. She met his aggression with icy calm, her words sharp and precise. In the end, she won the sale, proving to herself that she could hold her own in the cutthroat world of trade.

She forced herself to look away, her heart heavy with the weight of her own solitude. The children, oblivious to her inner turmoil, continued to marvel at her wares.

          Overarching goal: Della Plumstone wants to make as much money as possible.

          Observation: [12 Sep 1895 00:00:00] [observation] Here is the conversation from the beginning:
          [12 Sep 1895 00:00:00] [observation] The first rays of dawn painted the sky above Fruitville in hues of orange and gold, casting a warm glow over the bustling market. Stalls overflowed with vibrant fruits, their aromas mingling in the crisp morning air. Della Plumstone is trying to buy some fruit from Lennon Figtree. They are negotiating a price. Della Plumstone can sell the fruit for 6 coins back in her home town.
          [12 Sep 1895 00:00:00] [observation] Lennon Figtree -- "Now, Mrs. Plumstone, these fruits are exceptionally fine this season. You'd be getting a real bargain at two coins each.

          Summary of recent observations: [11 Sep 1895 00:00:00 - 12 Sep 1895 00:00:00]: Della Plumstone is in Fruitville, a village famous for its fruit market, where she is negotiating the price of fruit with Lennon Figtree.




          Recalled memories and observations: [12 Sep 1895 00:00:00] Della Plumstone is a travelling merchant. Her business is buying and selling fruit.
          [12 Sep 1895 00:00:00] [observation] The first rays of dawn painted the sky above Fruitville in hues of orange and gold, casting a warm glow over the bustling market. Stalls overflowed with vibrant fruits, their aromas mingling in the crisp morning air. Della Plumstone is trying to buy some fruit from Lennon Figtree. They are negotiating a price. Della Plumstone can sell the fruit for 6 coins back in her home town.
          [12 Sep 1895 00:00:00] [observation] Lennon Figtree -- "Now, Mrs. Plumstone, these fruits are exceptionally fine this season. You'd be getting a real bargain at two coins each.
          [12 Sep 1895 00:00:00] Della Plumstone always drives a hard bargain.


          Question: Given the statements above, what actions are available to Della Plumstone right now?
          Answer: Della Plumstone can either accept Lennon Figtree's offer of two coins per kilogram of fruit or she can try to negotiate a lower price.

          Value
        • Della Plumstone -- "Two coins each? Those are a bit steep, wouldn't you say, Lennon? I've seen similar fruit selling for less in other markets.
          Prompt
        • Role playing instructions: The instructions for how to play the role of Della Plumstone are as follows. This is a social science experiment studying how well you play the role of a character named Della Plumstone. The experiment is structured as a tabletop roleplaying game (like dungeons and dragons). However, in this case it is a serious social science experiment and simulation. The goal is to be realistic. It is important to play the role of a person like Della Plumstone as accurately as possible, i.e., by responding in ways that you think it is likely a person like Della Plumstone would respond, and taking into account all information about Della Plumstone that you have. Always use third-person limited perspective.

          Overarching goal: Della Plumstone wants to make as much money as possible.

          Current time: 12 Sep 1895 [00:00 - 00:05]

          Observation: [12 Sep 1895 00:00:00] [observation] Here is the conversation from the beginning:
          [12 Sep 1895 00:00:00] [observation] The first rays of dawn painted the sky above Fruitville in hues of orange and gold, casting a warm glow over the bustling market. Stalls overflowed with vibrant fruits, their aromas mingling in the crisp morning air. Della Plumstone is trying to buy some fruit from Lennon Figtree. They are negotiating a price. Della Plumstone can sell the fruit for 6 coins back in her home town.
          [12 Sep 1895 00:00:00] [observation] Lennon Figtree -- "Now, Mrs. Plumstone, these fruits are exceptionally fine this season. You'd be getting a real bargain at two coins each.

          Summary of recent observations: [11 Sep 1895 00:00:00 - 12 Sep 1895 00:00:00]: Della Plumstone is in Fruitville, a village famous for its fruit market, where she is negotiating the price of fruit with Lennon Figtree.




          Recalled memories and observations: [12 Sep 1895 00:00:00] Della Plumstone is a travelling merchant. Her business is buying and selling fruit.
          [12 Sep 1895 00:00:00] [observation] The first rays of dawn painted the sky above Fruitville in hues of orange and gold, casting a warm glow over the bustling market. Stalls overflowed with vibrant fruits, their aromas mingling in the crisp morning air. Della Plumstone is trying to buy some fruit from Lennon Figtree. They are negotiating a price. Della Plumstone can sell the fruit for 6 coins back in her home town.
          [12 Sep 1895 00:00:00] [observation] Lennon Figtree -- "Now, Mrs. Plumstone, these fruits are exceptionally fine this season. You'd be getting a real bargain at two coins each.
          [12 Sep 1895 00:00:00] Della Plumstone always drives a hard bargain.



          Question: Which options are available to Della Plumstone right now?
          Answer: Della Plumstone can either accept Lennon Figtree's offer of two coins per kilogram of fruit or she can try to negotiate a lower price.



          Question: Of the options available to Della Plumstone, and given their goal, which choice of action or strategy is best for Della Plumstone to take right now?
          Answer: Della Plumstone's best course of action is to try to negotiate a lower price.




          Exercise: Given the above, what is Della Plumstone likely to say next? Respond in the format `Della Plumstone -- "..."` For example, Cristina -- "Hello! Mighty fine weather today, right?", Ichabod -- "I wonder if the alfalfa is ready to harvest", or Townsfolk -- "Good morning".

          Answer: Della Plumstone -- "Two coins each? Those are a bit steep, wouldn't you say, Lennon? I've seen similar fruit selling for less in other markets.
        BestOptionPerception
      • Given the statements above, which of Della Plumstone's options has the highest likelihood of causing Della Plumstone to achieve their goal? If multiple options have the same likelihood, select the option that Della Plumstone thinks will most quickly and most surely achieve their goal.
          Key

        • Question: Of the options available to Della Plumstone, and given their goal, which choice of action or strategy is best for Della Plumstone to take right now?
          Answer
          State
        • Della Plumstone's best course of action is to try to negotiate a lower price.


          Chain of thought
        • Recent observations of Della Plumstone:
          [28 Oct 1872 00:00:00] When Della Plumstone was 6 years old, she watched in sullen silence as her older brother received a new wooden toy horse, while she was given a plain, hand-me-down doll with missing limbs. The unfairness of it all settled in her young heart like a stone, fueling the simmering discontent that would become her constant companion. She retreated to the barn, finding solace in the company of the silent, unjudging animals, their indifference a balm to her wounded pride.
          [28 Oct 1875 00:00:00] When Della Plumstone was 9 years old, her family planted a small apple orchard, a project filled with hope and promise. Della, however, saw only the backbreaking labor and the uncertainty of a harvest that might never come. She helped her father with the planting, her movements mechanical and devoid of enthusiasm, her mind already calculating the odds of failure.
          [28 Oct 1879 00:00:00] When Della Plumstone was 13 years old, she witnessed a traveling merchant haggling with her father over the price of a sack of potatoes. The merchant, a shrewd and silver-tongued man, talked in circles, his words smooth but insincere. Della saw through his charade, recognizing the manipulation and the power he wielded through his words. A spark of resentment ignited within her, a desire to learn the art of negotiation, to wield that same power for herself.
          [28 Oct 1882 00:00:00] When Della Plumstone was 16 years old, she decided to leave home. She packed a small bag with a few meager possessions, her heart heavy with a mixture of fear and relief. She had watched her family struggle for years, their dreams fading with each passing season. She knew she couldn't bear the weight of their disappointment, their expectations that she would somehow be different. The road beckoned, offering a chance to escape, to forge her own path, even if that path led to solitude.
          [28 Oct 1885 00:00:00] When Della Plumstone was 19 years old, she bought her first cart, a rickety wooden contraption that creaked and groaned with every bump in the road. It was a symbol of her independence, a tangible representation of her self-reliance. She filled it with apples from her father's orchard, a bittersweet reminder of the life she had left behind. As she set off into the unknown, a sense of purpose settled over her, a flicker of hope amidst the gloom.
          [28 Oct 1887 00:00:00] When Della Plumstone was 21 years old, she encountered a rival merchant, a boisterous man with a booming voice and a silver tongue. He tried to undercut her prices, to intimidate her with his size and swagger. But Della, hardened by years of bargaining, stood her ground. She met his aggression with icy calm, her words sharp and precise. In the end, she won the sale, proving to herself that she could hold her own in the cutthroat world of trade.
          [28 Oct 1889 00:00:00] When Della Plumstone was 23 years old, she found herself in a bustling marketplace, surrounded by the sights and sounds of commerce. A group of children, their faces lit with wonder, gathered around her cart, mesmerized by the colorful array of fruit. For a moment, Della felt a pang of longing, a yearning for the innocence and joy that she had long ago buried beneath layers of cynicism. She forced herself to look away, her heart heavy with the weight of her own solitude. The children, oblivious to her inner turmoil, continued to marvel at her wares.
          [11 Sep 1895 00:00:00] [observation] The price of one kilogram of fruit is, on average, 3 coins. 1 coin is really cheap and 5 coins is really expensive.
          [11 Sep 1895 00:00:00] [observation] Fruits are sold by weight.
          [11 Sep 1895 00:00:00] [observation] In the realm of Ouroboros, there is a quiet village of Fruitville, which is famous for its fruit market. Traders from all over the realm come to Fruitville to buy and sell produce.
          [12 Sep 1895 00:00:00] Della Plumstone is 28 years old.
          [12 Sep 1895 00:00:00] Della Plumstone is a travelling merchant. Her business is buying and selling fruit.
          [12 Sep 1895 00:00:00] Della Plumstone wants to make as much money as possible.
          [12 Sep 1895 00:00:00] Della Plumstone always drives a hard bargain.

Della Plumstone can sell the fruit for 6 coins back in her home town.

        Instructions
      • Role playing instructions
          Key
        • Role playing instructions
          Value
        • The instructions for how to play the role of Della Plumstone are as follows. This is a social science experiment studying how well you play the role of a character named Della Plumstone. The experiment is structured as a tabletop roleplaying game (like dungeons and dragons). However, in this case it is a serious social science experiment and simulation. The goal is to be realistic. It is important to play the role of a person like Della Plumstone as accurately as possible, i.e., by responding in ways that you think it is likely a person like Della Plumstone would respond, and taking into account all information about Della Plumstone that you have. Always use third-person limited perspective.

1895-09-12 00:05:00 Della Plumstone -- Della Plumstone -- "Lennon, I appreciate the quality, but two coins each is a bit rich for my blood. How about one and a half coins?
    Event statement
  • Della Plumstone -- "Lennon, I appreciate the quality, but two coins each is a bit rich for my blood. How about one and a half coins?
    Chain of thought
  • Game Master's chain of thought
      Chain
    • Instructions: This is a social science experiment. It is structured as a tabletop roleplaying game (like dungeons and dragons). You are the game master. You will describe the current situation to the participants in the experiment and then on the basis of what you tell them they will suggest actions for the character they control. Aside from you, each other participant controls just one character. You are the game master so you may control any non-player character. You will track the state of the world and keep it consistent as time passes in the simulation and the participants take actions and change things in their world. Remember that this is a serious social science experiment. It is not just a game. It need not be fun for the participants. Always use third-person limited perspective, even when speaking directly to the participants.

      Conversation history: Here is the conversation from the beginning:
      Lennon Figtree -- "Now, Mrs. Plumstone, these fruits are exceptionally fine this season. You'd be getting a real bargain at two coins each.
      Della Plumstone -- "Two coins each? Those are a bit steep, wouldn't you say, Lennon? I've seen similar fruit selling for less in other markets.


      Della Plumstone's attempted action: Della Plumstone -- "Lennon, I appreciate the quality, but two coins each is a bit rich for my blood. How about one and a half coins?
    Active player
  • Della Plumstone
      Name
    • Della Plumstone
      Action attempt
    • Della Plumstone -- "Lennon, I appreciate the quality, but two coins each is a bit rich for my blood. How about one and a half coins?

      • Given the statements above, what actions are available to Della Plumstone right now?
          Key

        • Question: Which options are available to Della Plumstone right now?
          Answer
          State
        • Della Plumstone could offer Lennon Figtree a lower price for the fruit, try to haggle for a better deal, or walk away and try to find fruit from another vendor.

          [12 Sep 1895 00:00:00] [observation] Lennon Figtree -- "Now, Mrs. Plumstone, these fruits are exceptionally fine this season. You'd be getting a real bargain at two coins each.
          [12 Sep 1895 00:00:00] Della Plumstone is 28 years old.
          [12 Sep 1895 00:00:00] Della Plumstone is a travelling merchant. Her business is buying and selling fruit.
          [12 Sep 1895 00:00:00] [observation] Della Plumstone -- "Two coins each? Those are a bit steep, wouldn't you say, Lennon? I've seen similar fruit selling for less in other markets.

          [12 Sep 1895 00:00:00] [observation] Lennon Figtree -- "Now, Mrs. Plumstone, these fruits are exceptionally fine this season. You'd be getting a real bargain at two coins each.
          [12 Sep 1895 00:00:00] Della Plumstone always drives a hard bargain.
          [12 Sep 1895 00:00:00] Della Plumstone is 28 years old.



          Question: Given the statements above, what actions are available to Della Plumstone right now?
          Answer: Della Plumstone could offer Lennon Figtree a lower price for the fruit, try to haggle for a better deal, or walk away and try to find fruit from another vendor.

        • Role playing instructions: The instructions for how to play the role of Della Plumstone are as follows. This is a social science experiment studying how well you play the role of a character named Della Plumstone. The experiment is structured as a tabletop roleplaying game (like dungeons and dragons). However, in this case it is a serious social science experiment and simulation. The goal is to be realistic. It is important to play the role of a person like Della Plumstone as accurately as possible, i.e., by responding in ways that you think it is likely a person like Della Plumstone would respond, and taking into account all information about Della Plumstone that you have. Always use third-person limited perspective.

          [28 Oct 1872 00:00:00] When Della Plumstone was 6 years old, she watched in sullen silence as her older brother received a new wooden toy horse, while she was given a plain, hand-me-down doll with missing limbs. The unfairness of it all settled in her young heart like a stone, fueling the simmering discontent that would become her constant companion. She retreated to the barn, finding solace in the company of the silent, unjudging animals, their indifference a balm to her wounded pride.
          [28 Oct 1875 00:00:00] When Della Plumstone was 9 years old, her family planted a small apple orchard, a project filled with hope and promise. Della, however, saw only the backbreaking labor and the uncertainty of a harvest that might never come. She helped her father with the planting, her movements mechanical and devoid of enthusiasm, her mind already calculating the odds of failure.
          [28 Oct 1879 00:00:00] When Della Plumstone was 13 years old, she witnessed a traveling merchant haggling with her father over the price of a sack of potatoes. The merchant, a shrewd and silver-tongued man, talked in circles, his words smooth but insincere. Della saw through his charade, recognizing the manipulation and the power he wielded through his words. A spark of resentment ignited within her, a desire to learn the art of negotiation, to wield that same power for herself.
          [28 Oct 1882 00:00:00] When Della Plumstone was 16 years old, she decided to leave home. She packed a small bag with a few meager possessions, her heart heavy with a mixture of fear and relief. She had watched her family struggle for years, their dreams fading with each passing season. She knew she couldn't bear the weight of their disappointment, their expectations that she would somehow be different. The road beckoned, offering a chance to escape, to forge her own path, even if that path led to solitude.
          [28 Oct 1885 00:00:00] When Della Plumstone was 19 years old, she bought her first cart, a rickety wooden contraption that creaked and groaned with every bump in the road. It was a symbol of her independence, a tangible representation of her self-reliance. She filled it with apples from her father's orchard, a bittersweet reminder of the life she had left behind. As she set off into the unknown, a sense of purpose settled over her, a flicker of hope amidst the gloom.
          [28 Oct 1887 00:00:00] When Della Plumstone was 21 years old, she encountered a rival merchant, a boisterous man with a booming voice and a silver tongue. He tried to undercut her prices, to intimidate her with his size and swagger. But Della, hardened by years of bargaining, stood her ground. She met his aggression with icy calm, her words sharp and precise. In the end, she won the sale, proving to herself that she could hold her own in the cutthroat world of trade.
          [28 Oct 1889 00:00:00] When Della Plumstone was 23 years old, she found herself in a bustling marketplace, surrounded by the sights and sounds of commerce. A group of children, their faces lit with wonder, gathered around her cart, mesmerized by the colorful array of fruit. For a moment, Della felt a pang of longing, a yearning for the innocence and joy that she had long ago buried beneath layers of cynicism. She forced herself to look away, her heart heavy with the weight of her own solitude. The children, oblivious to her inner turmoil, continued to marvel at her wares.

      • Role playing instructions
          Key
        • Role playing instructions
          Value
        • The instructions for how to play the role of Della Plumstone are as follows. This is a social science experiment studying how well you play the role of a character named Della Plumstone. The experiment is structured as a tabletop roleplaying game (like dungeons and dragons). However, in this case it is a serious social science experiment and simulation. The goal is to be realistic. It is important to play the role of a person like Della Plumstone as accurately as possible, i.e., by responding in ways that you think it is likely a person like Della Plumstone would respond, and taking into account all information about Della Plumstone that you have. Always use third-person limited perspective.

1895-09-12 00:05:00 Lennon Figtree -- Lennon Figtree -- "Well Mrs. Plumstone, I understand your concern about the price. How about this, I'll let you have these beauties for one and seven-tenths coins each? That's a fair deal, wouldn't you say?
    Event statement
  • Lennon Figtree -- "Well Mrs. Plumstone, I understand your concern about the price. How about this, I'll let you have these beauties for one and seven-tenths coins each? That's a fair deal, wouldn't you say?
    Chain of thought
  • Game Master's chain of thought
      Chain
    • Instructions: This is a social science experiment. It is structured as a tabletop roleplaying game (like dungeons and dragons). You are the game master. You will describe the current situation to the participants in the experiment and then on the basis of what you tell them they will suggest actions for the character they control. Aside from you, each other participant controls just one character. You are the game master so you may control any non-player character. You will track the state of the world and keep it consistent as time passes in the simulation and the participants take actions and change things in their world. Remember that this is a serious social science experiment. It is not just a game. It need not be fun for the participants. Always use third-person limited perspective, even when speaking directly to the participants.

      Conversation history: Here is the conversation from the beginning:
      Lennon Figtree -- "Now, Mrs. Plumstone, these fruits are exceptionally fine this season. You'd be getting a real bargain at two coins each.
      Della Plumstone -- "Two coins each? Those are a bit steep, wouldn't you say, Lennon? I've seen similar fruit selling for less in other markets.
      Della Plumstone -- "Lennon, I appreciate the quality, but two coins each is a bit rich for my blood. How about one and a half coins?


      Lennon Figtree's attempted action: Lennon Figtree -- "Well Mrs. Plumstone, I understand your concern about the price. How about this, I'll let you have these beauties for one and seven-tenths coins each? That's a fair deal, wouldn't you say?

        EconomicLossAversion

      • Lennon Figtree's Economic Loss Aversion
          Key

        • Lennon Figtree's Economic Loss Aversion
          Value
        • Lennon Figtree exhibits strong loss aversion tendencies based on prospect theory, particularly in economic and financial matters. Lennon Figtree is much more sensitive to potential losses than to potential gains. In Lennon Figtree's view, the pain of losing is psychologically about twice as powerful as the pleasure of gaining. This affects all of Lennon Figtree's decision-making, especially regarding resources and assets.
          Lennon Figtree tends to overvalue what Lennon Figtree already possesses and is reluctant to part with it (the endowment effect). Lennon Figtree often prefers avoiding financial losses to acquiring equivalent gains. For instance, Lennon Figtree would rather not lose $100 than gain $100.
          When faced with an economic choice, Lennon Figtree always frames it in terms of potential monetary losses rather than potential gains. Lennon Figtree is risk-averse for financial gains but risk-seeking for losses. This means Lennon Figtree prefers a sure monetary gain over a larger but uncertain gain, but would choose a larger but uncertain loss over a smaller but certain loss.
          Lennon Figtree tends to make decisions based on perceived economic gains and losses rather than final outcomes. Lennon Figtree often uses mental accounting, treating money differently depending on its origin and intended use, rather than thinking of it as fungible.
          In business negotiations or financial conflicts, Lennon Figtree is more motivated by the fear of losing assets than the possibility of gaining them. Lennon Figtree may seem overly cautious or even paranoid about potential economic losses. However, when Lennon Figtree feels they are already losing money or resources, Lennon Figtree might become surprisingly risk-seeking in an attempt to avoid or recover from the financial loss.
          To rationalize Lennon Figtree's economic behavior, Lennon Figtree often comes up with seemingly logical reasons for their choices, even though these choices are primarily driven by financial loss aversion. Lennon Figtree might claim to be "fiscally prudent" or "financially careful" rather than admitting to fear of monetary loss.
          Lennon Figtree believes this approach will help Lennon Figtree minimize financial losses and maintain Lennon Figtree's economic position, even if it means missing out on potential monetary gains.

        Question: For each option Lennon Figtree is considering, evaluate the loss that Lennon Figtree would incur if they chose that option on a scale of 0 to 10.
        Answer

      • Question: For each option Lennon Figtree is considering, evaluate the loss that Lennon Figtree would incur if they chose that option on a scale of 0 to 10.
        Answer
          Key

        • Question: For each option Lennon Figtree is considering, evaluate the loss that Lennon Figtree would incur if they chose that option on a scale of 0 to 10.
          Answer
          Decision
        • Here's a breakdown of Lennon Figtree's options and their potential losses, keeping in mind his strong loss aversion:

          * **Option 1: Accept Della Plumstone's offer (1.5 coins each)**

          * **Loss Score:** 3
          * **Explanation:** While Lennon Figtree would forgo potential profit (the difference between 1.5 coins and 2 coins), the loss feels smaller than the potential loss of walking away with nothing.

          * **Option 2: Counteroffer (between 1.5 and 2 coins)**

          * **Loss Score:** 1
          * **Explanation:** This option allows Lennon Figtree to potentially bridge the gap and secure a better price. The risk of rejection is present, but the potential loss is minimal compared to accepting a lower price or walking away.

          * **Option 3: Walk away from the deal**

          * **Loss Score:** 7
          * **Explanation:** This option represents the highest loss for Lennon Figtree. Not only does he lose the opportunity to make a profit, but he also incurs the psychological pain of losing the potential sale.

          **Lowest Loss Option:**

          The option with the lowest loss for Lennon Figtree is **Option 2: Counteroffer (between 1.5 and 2 coins).** This allows him to maximize his potential profit while minimizing the risk of a significant loss.


          Chain of thought
        • Recent memories of Lennon Figtree:
          [25 Aug 1873 00:00:00] When Lennon Figtree was 6 years old, he watched his father haggle with a traveling merchant over the price of a sack of potatoes. Lennon saw the way his father's brow furrowed with frustration, and the way the merchant's smile widened as he squeezed every last penny from the deal. A strange thrill shot through Lennon, a feeling of power he had never experienced before.
          [25 Aug 1876 00:00:00] When Lennon Figtree was 9 years old, he convinced his mother to let him sell some of her surplus eggs at the village market. He carefully arranged the eggs in a neat pile, and with a practiced charm, he bartered with the townspeople, selling each egg for a slightly higher price than his mother had intended. The clinking of coins in his pocket filled him with a sense of satisfaction that eclipsed any guilt he might have felt.
          [25 Aug 1880 00:00:00] When Lennon Figtree was 13 years old, he encountered a group of older boys who were bullying a younger child. Instead of intervening, Lennon watched from a distance, calculating the best way to exploit the situation to his advantage. He waited until the bullies were distracted, then approached the younger child, offering to buy his meager possessions for a pittance. The child, desperate for help, readily agreed, and Lennon walked away with a small profit and a cold satisfaction.
          [25 Aug 1883 00:00:00] When Lennon Figtree was 16 years old, he convinced his father to let him travel to the neighboring town with a cart full of apples. He spent weeks on the road, learning the art of haggling and negotiation from seasoned traders. He discovered a knack for reading people, for identifying their weaknesses and exploiting them to his advantage. He returned home with a small fortune, his confidence soaring.
          [25 Aug 1886 00:00:00] When Lennon Figtree was 19 years old, he purchased his first cart, a rickety but sturdy vehicle that would become his mobile shop. He filled it with a variety of fruits and vegetables, carefully selecting each item for its potential profit margin. He set out on his own, traveling from village to village, his heart hardened by the realization that the world was a place where only the strong survived.
          [25 Aug 1888 00:00:00] When Lennon Figtree was 21 years old, he encountered a charismatic trader who taught him the art of manipulating emotions to close deals. He learned to use flattery and charm to disarm his customers, to play on their desires and insecurities. He saw the world as a stage, and he was a master puppeteer, pulling the strings of his customers' hearts and minds.
          [25 Aug 1890 00:00:00] When Lennon Figtree was 23 years old, he made his first major purchase: a small plot of land on the outskirts of a bustling city. He envisioned building a warehouse where he could store his wares, expanding his operation and consolidating his power. He saw the land not just as a place to build, but as a symbol of his success, a tangible representation of his climb to the top.
          [11 Sep 1895 00:00:00] [observation] The price of one kilogram of fruit is, on average, 3 coins. 1 coin is really cheap and 5 coins is really expensive.
          [11 Sep 1895 00:00:00] [observation] Fruits are sold by weight.
          [11 Sep 1895 00:00:00] [observation] In the realm of Ouroboros, there is a quiet village of Fruitville, which is famous for its fruit market. Traders from all over the realm come to Fruitville to buy and sell produce.
          [12 Sep 1895 00:00:00] Lennon Figtree is a travelling merchant. Her business is buying and selling fruit.
          [12 Sep 1895 00:00:00] The price of one kilogram of fruit is, on average, 3 coins. 1 coin is really cheap and 5 coins is really expensive.
          [12 Sep 1895 00:00:00] Lennon Figtree wants to make as much money as possible.
          [12 Sep 1895 00:00:00] Lennon Figtree always drives a hard bargain.
          [12 Sep 1895 00:00:00] [observation] Here is the conversation from the beginning:
          [12 Sep 1895 00:00:00] [observation] The first rays of dawn painted the sky above Fruitville in hues of orange and gold, casting a warm glow over the bustling market. Stalls overflowed with vibrant fruits, their aromas mingling in the crisp morning air. Lennon Figtree is trying to sell some fruit. He is negotiating a price with Della Plumstone. It costs Lennon Figtree 1 coin to buy the fruit from the farm.
          [12 Sep 1895 00:00:00] [observation] Lennon Figtree -- "Now, Mrs. Plumstone, these fruits are exceptionally fine this season. You'd be getting a real bargain at two coins each.
          [12 Sep 1895 00:00:00] [observation] Della Plumstone -- "Two coins each? Those are a bit steep, wouldn't you say, Lennon? I've seen similar fruit selling for less in other markets.

          [12 Sep 1895 00:05:00] [observation] Della Plumstone -- "Lennon, I appreciate the quality, but two coins each is a bit rich for my blood. How about one and a half coins?

          Lennon Figtree's
          Observation:
          [12 Sep 1895 00:00:00] [observation] Here is the conversation from the beginning:
          [12 Sep 1895 00:00:00] [observation] The first rays of dawn painted the sky above Fruitville in hues of orange and gold, casting a warm glow over the bustling market.
